name: 鄭以旋
objective: This course will teach the use of English in the field of economics and discuss such ideas as world economies, free trade and capitalism through the reading of relevant contemporary literature. In addition, the United Nation's Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) will be introduced. All areas of English proficiency (listening, speaking, writing, reading) in the context of economics and business will be considered.

scorePolicy:
Attendance policy:
Eight or more absences from Week 2 onwards will result in a grade of 0% for the course.   

Assessment:
Group presentation (speaking)　　　　20%
School Mid-term　　　　　　　　20%
Writing test*　　　　　　　　　　10%　　　　
Final exam* (reading and listening)　　　　40%
Attendance and participation　　　　10%　　　　

* At the lecturer’s sole discretion, a make-up Writing Test or Final Exam may be granted upon presentation of a valid proof of illness (medical certificate or record of hospitalization) within 10 days of the date of absence.
materials:
Textbook: NCKU ESP Program English for Economics

Readings (subject to change):

•　　Nick Srnicek, “Chapter 2: Platform Capitalism,” Platform Capitalism, 2016.
•　　Thomas Piketty, “Introduction,” Capital in the Twenty-first Century, 2013.
•　　Steven D. Levitt and Stephen J. Dubner, “Chapter 5: What Makes a Perfect Parent,” Freakonomics, 2005.
•　　Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo, “Chapter 1: MEGA Make Economics Great Again,” Good Economics for Hard Times, 2019.
